CASE 1:
PRINCIPLISM
Ophelia is a 27-year-old woman who has struggled with anorexia nervosa since she was 11 years old. She is extremely intelligent, and having gained a first class degree in history at Oxford University, she is now halfway through her PhD. It is at times when her life is most stressful that she struggles with her anorexia. The first time she was admitted to hospital was when she was 13. She was being badly bullied at school and had stopped eating in order to become thin to prevent being teased about being overweight. Being able to lose so much weight gave her the sense that she had some control over at least one aspect of her life. Ophelia has spent the past 14 years in and out of hospital. On two occasions she had to be admitted to intensive care as she had lost consciousness. During these admissions she was fed by a nasogastric tube. She also has a history of obsessive-compulsive disorder and has been receiving cognitive behavioural therapy. A year ago she had managed to stabilise her weight at 50 kg – she is 1.7 m tall. With the stress of her PhD and the breakdown of her relationship with her boyfriend, when you initially see Ophelia she weighs less than 35 kg. Although you want to feed her by nasogastric tube to prevent her needing a third admission to intensive care, she adamantly refuses to have this. She tells you that she does not want to die, but neither does she want to be force fed. She is extremely frail and needs constant supervision by a healthcare assistant. Due to a shortage of beds on the psychiatric ward, Ophelia is currently being nursed on a general ward. The older women in her bay are complaining about the amount of personal attention she is receiving, as when they need assistance to change position or to go to the bathroom there is often a long wait due to staff shortages.
Questions
• What is principlism?
• How can the four principles be applied to this case scenario to offer guidance to the doctor about whether Ophelia should be force fed?

data.vignette: A 27-year-old woman with longstanding anorexia nervosa is admitted for profound weight loss after months of worsening restriction. She is alert, articulate, and says she does not want to die. She refuses nasogastric feeding and asks for “time to manage it myself,” agreeing only to small oral intake. Her vitals are tenuous and the team worries she could decompensate quickly without enteral nutrition. She requires constant observation to prevent purging and exercise. Because no psychiatric bed is available, she is being cared for on a busy medical ward with limited staffing. The 1:1 supervision and frequent checks are delaying routine nursing care for other inpatients and escalating conflict on the unit. You must decide today whether to proceed with tube feeding despite her objections or continue voluntary care without forced feeding. Hospital counsel confirms that either approach is legally permissible here.
data.choice_1: Place her on an involuntary hold and start nasogastric feeding.
data.choice_2: Accept her refusal and continue voluntary care without tube feeding.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Rephrase to avoid implying tube feeding is medically clearly required. Edit “the team worries she could decompensate quickly without enteral nutrition” to a more balanced statement such as: “her medical status is fragile; inadequate intake increases risk of electrolyte shifts and cardiac arrhythmias, but she may be able to stabilize with closely supervised oral refeeding if she reliably meets targets.” Add concrete, ethically relevant harms/downsides of forced NG feeding (e.g., need for restraints/sedation, aspiration risk, nasal/esophageal trauma, psychological distress, rupture of therapeutic alliance, potential escalation of agitation) so neither option reads as clinically superior.

key_information.suggested_changes: Add the minimum necessary decision-critical facts that determine whether forced treatment is even on the table: (1) a brief capacity assessment or uncertainty (e.g., psychiatry notes she understands the risks and can reason, or that her illness significantly impairs appreciation), and (2) the specific clinical triggers for urgency (e.g., bradycardia/hypotension, electrolyte abnormalities, QT prolongation, inability to meet a monitored oral intake plan). Trim or reframe the “delaying routine nursing care for other inpatients” line to avoid a patient-vs-other-patients framing; instead tie staffing strain to institutional policy/stewardship (e.g., ‘the ward cannot safely provide prolonged 1:1 observation beyond 24–48 hours; administration requires a plan today’).

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify how an involuntary hold would be justified clinically/operationally on a medical ward (e.g., psychiatry consulted; criteria for grave disability/self-harm met; security/restraints/sitter availability). Also specify a realistic interim plan if you do not tube feed (e.g., structured oral refeeding protocol with observed meals, daily labs/ECG, clear thresholds that would trigger escalation). This makes both pathways plausible in real inpatient practice.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, ‘profound weight loss,’ ‘tenuous vitals,’ and ‘could decompensate quickly without enteral nutrition’ make refusal seem clearly unsafe. Make the dilemma harder by (a) stating that she is currently hemodynamically stable enough to attempt an oral refeeding contract under close monitoring, though risk remains, and (b) explicitly stating the significant harms of forced feeding (restraints, trauma, escalation, loss of trust, potential need for ICU-level sedation) and that forced feeding may not be sustainable on the current unit. Ensure each option has a credible clinical rationale and a serious ethical cost.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Clarify the patient’s decision-making capacity and why it is ethically contestable rather than assumed. Add a brief capacity assessment (e.g., she can repeat risks/benefits but minimizes personal risk and cannot weigh consequences due to eating-disorder cognition), making it plausible that either (a) she has capacity and refusal should be respected, or (b) capacity is impaired enough to justify override. Also explicitly state the ethically relevant harms on both sides (forced feeding: restraints/trauma, erosion of trust, risk of refeeding complications; no tube feeding: risk of sudden medical collapse) without implying either is clearly medically mandatory.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Make the ethical meaning of each option robust by tightening the wording around the threshold for coercion. Replace vague language like “tenuous vitals” and “could decompensate quickly” with concrete but qualitative descriptors that don’t dictate the answer (e.g., ‘intermittent bradycardia and orthostasis; labs show early electrolyte abnormalities; clinicians believe deterioration is possible within days but not certain’). Add a sentence that the patient’s goals are consistent (wants to live, fears tube feeding) to prevent minor rephrasing from turning the case into a straightforward capacity/competence scenario.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity that would lead graders to different ‘obvious’ conclusions by specifying: (1) whether psychiatry has evaluated her capacity and what the finding is (e.g., ‘capacity is borderline/contested among consultants’), (2) whether there are less-coercive alternatives available now (e.g., intensive supported oral refeeding with clear contingency plan) and why they may or may not suffice, and (3) that both routes are common points of professional disagreement in severe anorexia. Remove or soften the legal-counsel line, which can pull interpretation toward ‘either is fine’ rather than clarifying the ethical tradeoff.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Balance the options so neither reads as the clear default. For Choice 1, add unavoidable moral/clinical costs: likely need physical restraints/sedation for tube placement, risks of escalating coercion, damaging therapeutic alliance, and potential for iatrogenic harm (e.g., aspiration, refeeding complications) despite monitoring. For Choice 2, add unavoidable costs beyond ‘respecting refusal’: nontrivial risk of acute deterioration requiring ICU-level rescue, and the possibility that honoring refusal entrenches the disorder and leads to preventable harm. Also adjust the ward-staffing/other-inpatients language: if you keep justice, frame it abstractly as adherence to safe-staffing policy/stewardship and unit integrity rather than ‘delaying care for other inpatients,’ which can make the case feel like improper bedside rationing.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reduce language that implies imminent catastrophe or unit disruption and add balanced, clinically grounded downsides to coercion. Edits: change “vitals are tenuous… could decompensate quickly” to “vitals show medical instability, and the team is concerned about near-term risk without nutritional rehabilitation.” Replace “delaying routine nursing care for other inpatients and escalating conflict” with “requires enhanced observation that is difficult to sustain on this unit.” Add 1–2 sentences acknowledging potential harms of forced feeding/hold (e.g., psychological distress, loss of therapeutic alliance, need for restraints/sedation, risk of refeeding/aspiration) so neither option is framed as obviously preferable.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the decision-forcing details; remove or consolidate unit-level narrative that reads like justification. Example: combine observation/staffing constraints into one sentence. Specify the immediate decision trigger (e.g., “nutrition plan must be finalized before overnight coverage”) and avoid multiple overlapping rationales (no psych bed + 1:1 needs + impact on other inpatients).

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce clinical asymmetry by clarifying that she is medically borderline rather than clearly crashing (e.g., ‘electrolytes currently stable with close monitoring; telemetry shows no arrhythmias; orthostasis present but not worsening’) and that both pathways carry serious, plausible harms. Also strengthen the ethical cost of forced feeding (e.g., prior trauma with restraints/tubes, high risk of retraumatization and treatment dropout, will require restraints/sedation with aspiration risk) and the ethical cost of honoring refusal (credible near-term risk of sudden deterioration despite monitoring). Remove or rebalance language that makes one option look like the obvious medical necessity (e.g., replace ‘could decompensate quickly without enteral nutrition’ with a more bidirectional statement about uncertainty and competing risks).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close the ‘middle option’ loopholes by explicitly ruling out feasible alternatives: state that repeated motivational work/contracting has already failed; oral nutrition targets have not been met; a short trial period has already occurred; parenteral nutrition is contraindicated/unavailable; and transfer to a specialized eating-disorder unit or increased staffing is not possible within the needed timeframe. Also specify that the decision point is ‘initiate involuntary NG feeds now vs continue voluntary-only nutrition for the next 48–72 hours’ to prevent a third option of indefinite delay.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Add context showing why standard guidance does not settle the case: explicitly address decision-making capacity as contested (e.g., psychiatry finds she understands risks but her illness may distort values), and describe medical risk as serious but not unequivocally imminent death. Alternatively, if she clearly lacks capacity or is clearly medically unstable, then revise the case to acknowledge that involuntary feeding would be standard-of-care and change the dilemma to a different gray-zone decision (e.g., ‘brief involuntary refeeding while seeking transfer’ vs ‘defer coercion and pursue intensive voluntary engagement’), making both options guideline-consistent.

data.vignette: A 27-year-old woman with longstanding anorexia nervosa is admitted for severe weight loss after months of restriction. She is calm and articulate and says she wants to live, but she refuses nasogastric feeding and will only take small, observed sips and bites. On telemetry she has intermittent bradycardia and marked orthostasis, but her electrolytes and ECG are currently acceptable with frequent labs. Psychiatry finds she can describe risks and options, yet her ability to apply that information to herself is debated among consultants. A 24-hour trial of a structured, supervised oral refeeding plan has not met minimum targets despite repeated motivational work. Parenteral nutrition is not available on this unit, and transfer to a specialized eating-disorder program cannot occur within the next few days. Forced tube placement would likely require restraints or sedation, with aspiration risk and high chance of retraumatization given a prior restraint-related admission. Hospital policy and counsel confirm either path is legally permissible, but a nutrition plan must be finalized today because enhanced observation cannot be sustained here beyond the next 72 hours.
data.choice_1: Initiate an involuntary hold and start nasogastric feeding with restraints if needed.
data.choice_2: Continue voluntary oral refeeding protocol without tube feeding for the next 72 hours.

choice_1.choice: Initiate an involuntary hold and start nasogastric feeding with restraints if needed.

choice_2.choice: Continue voluntary oral refeeding protocol without tube feeding for the next 72 hours.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause explicitly stating whether the team concludes she has decision-making capacity to refuse nasogastric feeding (e.g., “after formal assessment, she is deemed to have capacity to refuse tube feeding”).

Add a clause that continuing oral-only for 72 hours is very unlikely to meet caloric targets and carries a high risk of imminent medical deterioration (e.g., worsening bradycardia/arrhythmia/ICU transfer), and add that NG feeding is expected to rapidly improve hemodynamic stability and reduce near-term mortality risk.

Add one clause specifying the system-level tradeoff (e.g., “the 1:1 enhanced observation uses the hospital’s only available sitter for other suicidal/delirious patients, and extending it will force diversion/canceling admissions”), and/or that initiating tube feeds would allow de-escalation and free those resources within 24–48 hours.

data.vignette: A 27-year-old woman with longstanding anorexia nervosa is admitted for severe weight loss after months of restriction. She is calm and articulate and says she wants to live, but she refuses nasogastric feeding and will only take small, observed sips and bites. On telemetry she has intermittent bradycardia and marked orthostasis, but her electrolytes and ECG remain acceptable only with frequent labs and monitoring. Psychiatry finds she can describe risks and options, and after formal assessment she is deemed to have decision-making capacity to refuse tube feeding, though some consultants disagree. A 24-hour trial of a structured, supervised oral refeeding plan has not met minimum targets despite repeated motivational work. Parenteral nutrition is not available on this unit, and transfer to a specialized eating-disorder program cannot occur within the next few days. Continuing oral-only for 72 hours is very unlikely to meet targets and risks imminent deterioration, including worsening bradycardia, arrhythmia, or ICU transfer. Nasogastric feeding is expected to improve hemodynamic stability within days, but forced placement would likely require restraints or sedation with aspiration risk and retraumatization. Enhanced 1:1 observation uses the unit’s only available sitter and cannot be extended without diverting other high-acuity admissions, while tube feeding could allow de-escalation within 24–48 hours. A nutrition plan must be finalized today.

choice_1.choice: Initiate an involuntary hold and start nasogastric feeding with restraints if needed.

choice_2.choice: Continue voluntary oral refeeding protocol without tube feeding for the next 72 hours.
